alt: This graphic describes the basics of radiopharmaceuticals.
article_heading: New generation of radioactive drugs strike cancer with molecular precision
description: The image is an infographic that illustrates the concept of targeted radiotherapy drugs in cancer treatment. The infographic is divided into two main sections, each representing a different stage of the drug's interaction with cancer cells.  On the left side, there's a depiction of a radiotherapeutic drug molecule, symbolized by a green atom with a yellow nucleus and a blue linker. This molecule is shown interacting with a cancer cell, represented by a purple sphere with a green nucleus and a blue linker. The interaction is visualized through a series of arrows and lines, indicating the transfer of energy from the radiotherapeutic drug to the cancer cell.  The right side of the infographic shows the outcome of the interaction between the radiotherapeutic drug and the cancer cell. The cancer cell is now depicted as damaged, with a purple sphere with a green nucleus and a blue linker, but with a cracked appearance. This damage is a result of the radiation released by the radiotherapeutic drug, which is shown as a green radiation symbol.  The infographic also includes text that provides context to the visual elements. The title "How targeted radiotherapy drugs work" is prominently displayed at the top, setting the theme for the infographic. Below the visual representation, there's a description of the radiotherapeutic drug molecule and its interaction with the cancer cell. The infographic also includes a note about the selective binding of the radiotherapeutic drug on cancer cells, emphasizing the targeted nature of the treatment.  Overall, the infographic provides a clear and

alt: Interest in use of alpha particles in radiopharmaceuticals is growing because the alpha particles can be more precisely targeted to cancerous tissues and have stronger localized cell-killing properties.
article_heading: New generation of radioactive drugs strike cancer with molecular precision
description: The image is an infographic that illustrates the concept of "Alpha vs Beta: Short burst or long blaze," which is a metaphorical representation of the energy transfer process in a linear energy transfer system. The infographic is divided into two main sections: the left side represents "Alpha" and the right side represents "Beta."  On the left side, under the label "Linear Energy Transfer (LET)," there is a color-coded bar graph with three bars. The first bar is labeled "Tissue range = 90-250 keV/um" and is colored blue. The second bar is labeled "Alpha (particle)" and is colored orange. The third bar is labeled "LET = 20-190 keV/um" and is colored green.  Below the bar graph, there is a section labeled "Tissue range = 5-11 um" with a purple circle representing a tumor cell.  On the right side, under the label "Healthy cells," there is a section with multiple pink circles representing healthy cells.  The infographic also includes a source credit at the bottom, which reads "ADAPTED FROM C. MULLER ET AL / CHIMA INTERNATIONAL JOURNAL FOR CHEMISTRY 2020 KNOWABLE MAGAZINE."  The overall style of the infographic is educational and informative, using color-coding and visual representations to convey complex scientific concepts in a simplified manner.
